content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Fantastic game. Why?1. zoom system means that you can scale what you see from the entire battlefield to the regimental markings on a single tank - vast improvements over the RUSE system as well, the funny counters no longer appear2. each battle escalates as it progresses BUT unlike RUSE which had a semi Age of Empres resource system, units appear appear from off of the board3. the whole meta-game, for the first battle you play you actually only have a few units available, you need to unlock others as you complete the campaigns, play other people e.c.t. - your strategy will therefore be reflected in your army, did you unlock the artillery, or the helicopters?4. I am actually a miniature wargamer, this game is like an epic version of my favourite game in real life - 'Battlegroup:Kursk' - there is a whole supply mechanic which means you have to really plan your offensives, and defensive moves.If you like strategy, real strategy, then you may just be looking at the best game ever, I cannot praise it enough. If you are not so sure then I have had friends who have played this game and not enjoyed it so much: it can be confusing, complicated and annoying at first, but getting past the learning curve is well worth it.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												For MP, go to the latest game in series. For SP - here comes longer story.Many people claim that WG:EE have best SP campaigns. They are story driven and thus appears more interesting than skirmish-like ones. But there is one, massive problem existing - balance. Campaigns were not easy and thats good, since challange is part of having fun. But they are no longer just hard - many got elevated to "impossible" level due to patches, nerfs and, more importantly - massive AI buffs.AI simply cheats, as the last try to make it "challange". It dont need recon, ignore "line of sight" rules, can replenish ammunition and fuel before your very eyes, spawn units out of thin air, stay invisible next to your own recon units and so on. Performance was boosted in latest patches, making SP campaign missions unbalanced and nearly all old guides obsolete.There is no fun in that anymore, just frustration, abusing the system and beding the rules, simply to compete with cheating AI.I managed to beat the game but was it something to be proud of? No, I just felt glad that this is over.Dont believe the lies about SP campaigns. Get Red Dragon, if you want multiplayer but stay away from EE.

Posted: May 31, 2015
Meticulous & enjoyably taxing // Recommended for deep-strategy fanatics+ Zooming from ground to strategic view is absolutely seamless+ Persistent battle groups; units retain experience and losses are final+ Can play as NATO or Warsaw Pact forces+ Skirmish game mode is available, in addition to a thick campaign+ Unit unlock system is excellent, and encourages play of both single- and multi-player; this increases incentive and replayability+ Deck customization adds to the emphasis of strategy and the need to be prepared for future matches (particularly online)+ Vehicles, commands, and terrain are all extremely detailed in just about every facet+ Fantastic, challenging AI that punishes mistakes quickly and adopts well to the player's actions+ Boasts an absolutely superb audio design; gunfire feels weighted and satisfying+ Every bullet and shell is rendered; physics engine handles fire exchange beautifully+ Single-player has meat enough to be worth the price as it is (and multi-player is arguably the main focus)- Decently large learning curve that will certainly turn away those less experience in the genre- Requires creation of a 3rd party account- Lackluster and largely unhelpful in-game tutorialLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Against popular opinion, I will state mine. Wargame: European Escalation, is the BEST title in the Wargame series IF you are a fan of old-school RTS like I am. This game stays truer to its roots than any other game in the series. Missing only the base building.+Good graphics that hold up even today.+/-A campaign mode that allows you to mission-by-mission test new units and get the hang of the game mechanics. Unfortunately this campaign isn't very interesting.+Truly competitive up to 4v4 RTS battles.+Strategic environments where marching tanks into cities is suicide, marching infantry through fields is suicide, and approaching any forest can lead to instant death from what tricky enemy awaits within. Helicopters are a powerful tool indeed, but be careful or else anti-air will take your prized Apache.+The sounds of the weapons are something you can feel, they hold up quite nicely.+/- PvE is present as you can have matches versus bots that hold up in fun. However just as the campaign was lackluster, the AI is as well. It becomes very predictable and boring without the dynamic of a real player.-There's an annoying blue line on the screen that never goes away.I give this game a 9/10 and will personally deem it the best game in the entire Wargame Franchise. Wheras the newer games really changed how they view "RTS", this game keeps the classic tactical gameplay many of us are used to, minus the base building. My friends all wanted me to play Airland battle (The sequel) though this one kept me hooked. It's so much more of a classic, and I'd definitely recommend anyone play this. Make sure you bring friends though, as this multiplayer is abandoned and dead for the most part.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												This really feels like the strategic war game we were waiting for since the invention of the genre. (Actually, it's like most other RTS's, played on a tactical level of warfare).This game has a very realistic feel to it. At all times, all your actions are truly part of the road to the final result of the mission.If anything surprising happens which sets you back, it's because you didn't prepare for it. And surprises will happen, you will be off guard, the AI will hit you hard at some point.There are some unfortunate flaws to make it a truly brilliant game. Win or defeat is not permanent, missions are replayable to improve your score. This game lends itself to make results more permanent. So that win or defeat would influence the war instead of a pre-determined sequence of missions. Unfortunately, Eugen Systems didn't implement that.Still, it feels like the Real Time Strategy game we all have been waiting for. After playing it, we are simply waiting for the improvement on it.8/10 very good game, a must play for fans of the genre, but still a lot of room for improvement

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												One of the best RTS games that i've ever played. Wargame: European Escalation is set in the cold war around the 1970's in a Nato vs Pact conflict. This game makes you think, such as what units you will need to use in battle. Sure, having a strong group of tanks is nice but you will also need anit-aircraft artillary in case of an oppenent launching an air attack. From what I have seen, there's always a counter unit to a unit. So basically if your oppenent does things right, he could destroy any of your units and you could destroy any of his. It all depends on the strategy you use. The single player has an interesting campaign and is challenging even on the easiest difficulty. There are not many people playing multiplayer, but you can find at least 1-2 matches a day. You are awarded command stars after completing tasks in mission or leveling up in muliplayer. Command stars allow you to purchase new vehicles for your armies. This will leave you playing for hours so you can unlock the tanks you want or a helicopter that looks cool. This game has a friendly community and I strongly recommend it to anyone interested in RTS games, or just strategy games in general.

												Anyone who whines about the single player difficulty is frankly just not trying hard enough. I completed the first and seconds campaigns (for the second time), today. content:
Posted: January 3
Product received for free
Basic InformationTitle:  Wargame: European EscalationDeveloper:  Eugen SystemsPublisher:  Focus Home InteractiveGenre:  Real Time StrategyGeneral ImpressionThe first part in the Wargame series of tactical RTS’ had to leave a good impression. Fortunately for it, the dev team behind the game I’m reviewing today, are industry veterans which specialize in the Real Time Strategy genre and particularly the subgenre I’m most found of, when strategic titles come into discussion. The type of strategy that eschews traditional base building and management, for pure unit combat. This subgenre relies however on a lot more patience, studying of the terrain and even your foes, to know precisely what weapons or tactics to use upon. It’s a lot more static than the fast-paced RTS’ so popular today. Starcraft, C&C, Dawn of War, Cossacks, Age of Empires and many other franchises, are as dynamic as they come, with players scrambling to meet their opponents in the open as soon as possible and the infrastructure needed to sustain your army, has to be built fast and efficiently while being maintained at all times with a  various degree of attention.By  contrast, franchises like: Sudden Strike, Blitzkrieg, Men of War, World in Conflict and Wargame, all focus on the skill of your unit placement, use and knowledge of the battlefield. There is no emphasis placed on a base since you rely on a steady or less, supply of reinforcements. Many times, you even get to choose those new units to enter the fray. It is far more realistic than building a barracks and watching troops march from it. And when you can no longer count on a near infinite number of units recruited through resource gathering, you begin to appreciate them far more and do your best as to limit the casualties sustained by your army.Wargame: European Escalation is by no means, an easy game. For some new players to this type of RTS, it may come as a nasty surprise, but even your most advanced tanks can fall prey to a well placed squad of rocket launcher-carrying infantry, hidden in a forest. Scouting ahead and before you send your mechanized units, is paramount. Even the falsely portrayed in the media, “death from above” type of assault helicopters, seem fragile and vulnerable if you don’t plan ahead accordingly. There is no “Rock Paper Scissors” ruleset in Wargame. This potential vulnerability of your units can also tip the odds in your favor since the enemy is also subject to the same tactics he might use against you. Alas, the Artificial Intelligence in this game, is quite capable and will not hesitate to flank you instead of just rushing towards the center of the battle. During some missions, it demonstrates full defensive skills and taking over sectors from the enemy shall not prove an easy task. I will not spoil details regarding the single player campaigns, even if I was pleased by the use of an alternative Cold War era in which the conflicts heat up faster than an ICBM heading for a capital city. That’s an abbreviation for “Intercontinental ballistic missile” by the way. The true “city busters” of our contemporary times.Unto the gameplay aspects I didn’t enjoy as much (and which ultimately stopped me from giving this title a perfect 10 rating). Besides being a difficult strategic game, you also have to babysit your units a lot more than in the aforementioned dynamic RTS types. Also, you can’t afford to lose too many units since they have a finite number for the entire campaign and unlocking new ones requires a lot of grinding (multiplayer matches are a must, in this case). You won’t be able to unlock all the units for both the NATO and the Warsaw Pact factions, just by completing the single player campaigns, no matter how many secondary objectives you might accomplish. I understand that far better than the already tough AI, would be a real mind, a human player to spar within an MP mode. I just don’t appreciate being forced down this road, in order to unlock a full roster of troops I might actually need during the SP missions.All things considered, European Escalation is the start of a great strategic series, in the vein of old school classics that can’t be found on the Steam Store (I’m looking at you, Sudden Strike!). And if you are searching for a derivative Cold War scenario about to get warmer than Hell itself, you’re in for a treat. Wargame doesn’t fail to provide a most challenging and fun experience. Once you’re used to the turtle pacing and battlefield unpredictability, you will really feel like an armchair general!Strong Points+ Gorgeous graphics.+ Excellent level design and AI.+ Steam Achievements.Weak Points- Micromanaging the entire battlefield is a necessity.- No Steam Trading Cards.- Unlocking all the units requires too much grinding.Rating 9/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes, through the generous contribution of Cubë.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I really hate that I have to call this game terrible, but sadly I do.  For me, it is almost unplayably bad, and I wish I had never wasted my money on it.The gameplay mechanics are good; it is sometimes difficult to micromanage the orientation of platoons to keep them facing the enemy, and my recon helicopters have an annoying tendency to land whenever they're not actively moving, while I may want them to stay airborne to keep enemy units visible; the inability to set stances, and the rather awkward method of turning off individual weapons on individual units to keep control of who fires what, can be annoying, but I can generally get my units to do what I want.  The graphics are fantastic, making each unit distinct and identifiable.  The music fits the scene nicely, and the single player campaign storyline is nicely plausible.So why do I call it terrible?  Becuase of the awful, terrible, abysmal AI.  In single player, the game becomes almost unplayable, all thanks to the AI's absolute omniscience.  Don't get me wrong, AIs have been able to see all the units on the field right back to the dawn of the RTS era, but it was generally not that big a deal.  In Wargame, however, recon is a central element of any army's tactics.  It requires careful attention to the type of recon vehicle, and equally careful scouting of suspected enemy strong points to avoid putting your recon vehicle in harms way.  The AI does none of that.  It just drops a full attack force directly on top of you, knowing exactly where all of your forces are at all times.  it is even worse in the campaign, where the AI will face you with overwhelming numbers in every mission, often pre-positioned in ambush sites that you can take no advantage of.  This severely reduces the tactics available, and ends up in a situation where the only way to make any sensible progress is by spamming the Quicksave key every time something doesn't go horribly wrong.I play single player.  I enjoy playing single player so I can take my time and explore my options.  But this game makes single player a horrible, crippled experience that is more like a chore than a game.  For your own sanity, Avoid at all costs.

Posted: May 7, 2015
												Ok, so coming as a fan of the RTS genre I enjoyed the game.  It was good, not great, but good. I liked that it required a certain degree of strategy aside from "make more tanks, blow people away." which is good.  I disliked the fact that the AI doesnt really change up its beginning round movements at all so that if you replay something you know where everything is going to be from the start. Secondly, I HATE that the AI somehow knows all about my position and troop movements and has acts in turn to counter everything I try to do.  In strategy games that is probably the biggest mistake a developer can make. That doesnt add challenge, it just pisses people off because they're not as clairvoyant as the AI. The player actually needs those scouts and recon units to see jack, while the AI somehow just knows these things and picks off your units making it frustrating to get good scores without playing level over and over. Overall, I would recommend the game, but only to those who already enjoy tough strategy games.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Insanely difficult and insanely addictive.There is only one difficulty in this game. Really hard and realistic. It is almost like a puzzle game with military units. You have a really hard task to achieve, and very often limited time to achieve it. Most of the time you are outnumbered by a superior enemy and must use the advantages of each unit to complete the task.This is really hard core rts simulation with units created to be as close to the real thing as possible. The tactics that the AI opponent uses are also supposed to be realistic, probing etc. But mostly you are outnumbered and have to use the scarce resources at your disposal to win.The command and control system, like all rts games are to some degree lacking. You have to both have the overview of the battlefield and also micro-manage units. This can lead to losing control and oversight, and you have to make sure to keep your flanks covered. There is a reason why all (functional) armies have ranks of officers to handle different levels of command. Mostly the units handles themselves intelligently and uses the most effective weapon at the time. This game is not for everyone since it is a hard-core simulation game. It is not a casual game. Think of it as ARMA only as a RTS. However if you really like strategy games/rts games or are a military "buff", I would recommend it. It is periodically on sale for 50-75% off since it is a few years old, so I would reccomend buying it on sale or trying a demo or seeing some youtube videos before buying since it is a game that you will either love or hate.I don´t think there is MP in this game anymore. I think that the SP is good enough. There is newer games which might have MP (Red Dragon is the latest).

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Excellent game. This is, in my view, the best of the Wargame series, despite being the oldest. The reason is that this is the only entry in the series with a proper single-player campaign.The seuqels, Airland battle and Red Dragon, dropped the scripted campaign in favour of a dynamic campaign. On the face of it, a synamic campaign sounds great—it's different every time so you get infinite replayability, right? The problem is that the campaign battles in those games are little more than glorified skirmishes against AI bots. European Escalation, on the other hand, has a fully-scripted campaign where a real, human designer has taken the time to think carefully about the narative that links the missions together, the design of the maps to support the specific missions that take place there, and the placement of each individual enemy unit. The result is a much tighter, more compelling single-player experience. in fact, I would say that this game is one of the top three single-player RTS games of all time.A key draw for the Wargame series is the multiplayer. European Escalation's multiplayer is good, but Airland Battle and Red Dragon are probably the better multiplayer games—they have more unit variety and more active communities. Multiplayer in Wargame is fantastic, so you should definitely check those two sequels. But anyone interested in a single-player RTS experience could do much much worse than giving European Escalation a shot.

												Wonderful strategy game. Unlike most RTS tactical use of terrain is crucial, and an ambush can easily take out the most powerful units. All units you'll find in the game are real-world units from the cold war era, and there's an incredible amount of them! Just learn to read their stats and their basic role and you shouldn't be overwhelmed though.Graphics are both impressive (smooth strategic zoom like R.U.S.E. or Supreme Commander, very detailed units and ground) and a bit bland (maps look all alike and very generic... at least it makes them easy to read).Campaign is a bit generic but is a very good challenge, you definitely won't breeze through the missions. Multiplayer was still alive last time I checked, but if that's your main interest you'd better buy the latest game in the series (Wargame: Red Dragon at the time of writing this) as that's where most of the community is.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Woww,This game is a RTS in all its essence. Ok you don't need to come from Harvard to get to understand basic unit movement and functions. Although understanding how all units can be strategized and played through for minimum casualty or maximum efficiency is really what makes this game shine through and through. The AI is really decent, more in tune with trigger functions and time base functions but one in all the solo game gets really freaking intense as you progress through solo modes and requires you to develop new strategy and so understand how the game is played as well as developing deeper understanding and meaning for each type of unit you can use and in what situation.Do you get kicked or asked to leave public MPs because you are a low level, yes you are. But you can always open your own public game and you will get to play MP games regardless. Although I strongly suggest to finish all Solo games mode first. It is like a pre-ambule to what is asked in MP mode and really far from easy to grasp a total win at firt sight.I am not a RTS fan per se, yet, I am enjoying this game. Perhaps I enjoy the gameplay mechanics and strategy deepens the game overall to the point where winning is THE greatest reward long time not seen in a vast majority of video games?!?!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												So, after many different strategies and tactics, I have finally come to an unsatisfying conclusion. This game is a trainwreck.Let me start off with the good parts about the game.THE GOOD THINGS:So, the graphics for a game on a scale such as this are amazing. The overall look of every unit is pretty good and you can clearly see that the developers did try to optimize the game as well.There is a decent tutorial system in the game as well. From the first mission, it tells you what you must do and so on, and after the first few missions, the game lets your hand go and lets you think on your own.That's just about it for the good things. Time for a good spank.THE BAD THINGS:So, let me start off with the enemy AI. In the Singleplayer Campaign, the AI seems to be an all-seeing entity that knows your every move, every tactic and attempted strategy, and immediately counters it, or makes it useless by annihilating your heaviest armored units. It's just impossible to fool this AI, no matter how hard I try, unless I guess where his line is the weakest and blast through there with whatever I can. This kills the overall fun of a fictional conflict RTS for me.Next up: BALANCEThere are some serious balancing issues between units of similar roles in the game, like, the M60 Patton being unable to stand up to a T-60 or a T-72 whatsoever. As an example, I had four M60 Patton's engage against three T-60's, both stock versions and at full HP, however, the T-60's somehow, magically, one-shotted my Patton's, even though both groups had their frontal armor aimed at one another, AND to top it all off, my tanks never managed to hit them, despite the distance being probably optimal for late 20th century tank battles - 500 meters.Third point: COMPUTER GETS AN UPPER HANDAt the start of every defense mission, the computer seems to have at least fifteen times more points that it can use to call upon reinforcements than the player. As an example, I was playing ABLE ARCHER's second mission, Ramstein Airbase or something like that, and I was able to call upon only three full squads of my finest armored units, M1 Abrams tanks. I placed them strategically where they were needed the most, but then the AI picked them all off almost 10 minutes after the start of the battle. The tanks were at full health, all of them had Corporal's stripes, but, they were just swarmed over by T-72's with missiles. I couldn't summon any other units because I didn't have a magical point income rate that the AI seemingly has.Fourth: MAGIC INFANTRYAs the title says, the game has magic infantry units that can fire hand-held AT rockets on the move. No weapon that I know of is capable of being fired on the move. The result of this on-the-move shot should would fly away from its intended target, really far. And then Infantry is overpowered, by being able to one shot even heavy Main Battle Tanks.Fifth point:All the tanks are horribly underrated or overrated. The M1 Abrams seemingly has really bad equipment, while, to my knowledge, the Abrams was one of the best and most technologically advanced tanks of its time when it first came out. And the T-80 seems to be the single most capable tank of the game, able to utterly annihilate squads of Abrams and Leopard 2 tanks that are even outflanking it. Yes, this actually happened to me.Sixth: TACTICS? I THINK NOT!So, this game promotes a lot of thinking, but this clearly isn't a thinking man's game. It's a cheating man's game. What I mean is, no tactic has any value on the battlefield whatsoever. For example, I set my batallion in a formation where my flanks are stronger than my middle, to make sure that I can outflank my enemy and surround him in a powerful pincer move. But that doesn't work because the AI can do whatever the hell it wants and summon units out of nowhere to outflank my tanks and one-shot them all with incredible accuracy.Seventh: ACCURACYSo, why do all of the player units suddenly have godawful accuracy and spotting range? I counted that at least 83% of all of my shots missed while they were in optimal engagement range, but for the AI - 67% was a miss at long range. The statistic is clearly showing how the AI wins in this and I am fully aware that the statistics for both factions are more or less balanced. It's still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Eighth: MICRO- AND MACRO-MANAGEMENTThis game supports management on a small and massive scale, and it's applaudable. Games like this are a rarity and ones that execute it perfectly are a luxury among the rare ones, but Wargame isn't that luxury. The management is a huge distraction because your units have no versatility and they can't think for themselves. They're literally civilians given a gun and then shooting anything that moves, not trained soldiers that must do what they're told to do.My personal verdict:Don't waste your money on Wargame, get RUSE instead. Or better yet, if you want a Cold War-era game, get World in Conflict. It is a far better game, executed masterfully, unlike this poor excuse for a ''Wargame'' where everything is out of place.NOTE: Don't give me that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I must suck in this game. I've been playing RTS games for ages, and this game simply does NOT in ANY DARN WAY reward tactical/strategic thinking. It's all RNG.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												One of my favorite RTS games. In this RTS game, instead of focusing on resource gathering and management or building up a base, you have a "deck" of units to work with. You can customize these decks with units you have unlocked. And once you start a match with a deck you can only use those units in the fight. You only have a limited number of each unit so don't just spam tanks or artillery units because you will run out very fast. In order to win you have to achieve a certain amount of points (ex:3500pts). You get points by destroying enemy units. Don't spam units and expect to win. You can't win with only tanks. You have to flank, use combined units to force your way into enemy controlled areas. Does the enemy have a heavily defended sector? Bombard them with artillery to dwindle there force and then move your garrisons in. You also have to worry about fuel and ammo. You will need a constant supply of ammo trucks to keep your units functional.Some cons I do have with the game are in fact the decks. It can be kind of tedious or grindy to have to unlock all of the units. It would be much easier to have them all unlocked at the start and just let you build it. But instead you are constantly playing matches to get stars to unlock better units. Another slight issue would be the learning curve. The game doesn't really explain itself well so trying to figure out what is what and what does what can be confusing at first and may be a turn off for some players. Over all I would rate this game 8/10. Very fun.

It has a bit of a learning curve and not much in the way of a tutorial, but it's well worth persevering.The mechanics are quite deep. Your units need constanst resupply since they run out of ammo, fuel, and armor. You must always be aware of your surroundings; scouting is one of the most important aspects of the game. You need to learn to both micro and macro-manage which can be challenging.Both singleplayer and multiplayer modes are fun. The game lacks some polish and is a bit rough around the edges, but it is well worth it.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												Wargame:EE is a mostly realistic RTS of which the setting is Europe during 1965-1975. You play as either a PACT or NATO country during the Cold War when all hell brakes loose. You use everything but Navy and Air Force in this game, to control strategic points, control high ground and set up ambushes on your enemy. You need to strategically place everything from ATGM's to recon units to almost every significant tank variant in the world at that time (T-55, T-62, T-72, T-80, M48 Super, M1 Abrams, Leopard 2A1) or you will lose. This isn't the type of RTS you can spam factories and a single unit and win, there are no factories and you need strategy. You also have to worry about logistics, for example, a ATGM soldier only carries from 6-12 rockets, you will need supply trucks close by to keep him full on ammo. All in all they created a pretty good game 8/10, my only quarrel with it is the command stars system, It takes entirely way too long unlock your multiplayer "deck" so you suffer with low level tanks as others still playing mp are running full decks, that, and the units you unlock in the difficult campaign do not carry over, but still very minor annoyances.

												I really enjoy this game, despite the sometimes insane difficulty. I've had a really hard time playing Warsaw Pact. The AI is merciless and relentless. The graphics work well for it and the game plays quite speedy on a modern PC. I've had no technical problems playing on Windows 10 x64 (or Windows 7 x64).I'm an old school wargamer and this satisfies that enjoyment and has a modern feel being RTS. So, buy this if: You like semi-realistic RTS, modern warfare, a real challenge, an excellent set of single player campaigns. You may not like this if high-difficulty is off-putting or you are expecting more of a game-style RTS with base building and such.

Posted: July 14, 2012
												Best spin on RTS gaming I've played in a while.Think of this game as a sort of "Total War: Cold War Gone Hot"Since tastes greatly differ, I'll just list some points here that stood out to me in comparison to standard-fare RTS games.> No base building> Very little micro-ing on unit-level> Focus on tactical placement/cover> Huge(!) selection of military gear> Huge armies> Huge maps> Easy to learn, hard to master> Strong focus on multiplayerPro:+ Good, fluid controls/UI/camera control+ Good visuals, good sound+ Good performance+ Excellent zoom levels/transitions+ Satisfactory impact of weapons+ Autonomous units act clever most of the time+ Good pacing of gameplay+ Multiplayer is fun even for beginnersCon:- Campaign is a bit short- Campaign difficulty can be a bit hard for new players- Unit placement in cover _can_ be a tiny bit fiddly at rare times- Not much handholding/tutorial help (lrn2play, nub :P)- Music is a bit weak, but not gratingI'm loving it!

												   A modern RTS  game that takes place Eastern Europe, during the Cold War. The game has a unique game mechanic that, uses tickets to call in for reinforcements (units). No micromanging resources or recruiting units, like other games in the genre. Another couple of unique feature that sets War Game European Escalation apart from other RTSs, is it doesn't use the typical rock, paper, scissors format often used and varied and diverse selection of units. Overall an excellent game 10/10

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Good stratgey game that really lets you think like a military commander, controls are fluid if you know what you are doing (basically just point and click), and you really need to think things thorugh frist. the graphics are decentbasically, the story is what would happen if the soviet union and nato got into a conflict over the berlin air lift crisis (that was when nato forces tried to fly into eastern germany to air drop supplies to the germans), basically the ussr invades western germany and the us and other coalition forces enter europt to stop them. in the game, you choose your attack force, which consists of things like infantry, tanks, support vehicles, anti-air trucks, etc. and then you take control of different regions on the map to eventually control the entire area. you have to carefully, and intelligently choose your strike force, because you only get reinforcements if your chosen units are destroyed.along the way you earn points that let you upgrade the units at your disposal gaining access to better tanks and helicopters

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I think the issue that bugs me the most is that units usually don't do what you tell them.This game models unit morale: units will freak out and run if they come under heavy fire (or somebody stubs their toe on a rock), or become stunned and stuck in place when saturated with rockets. I'm not talking about that. I'll have perfectly healthy, calm units near a FOB or maneuvering across empty terrain and they can't follow simple instructions. I've had infantry refuse to get in transports right next to them, infantry refuse to move out of cover, units deciding to stand out in an open field when I've explicitly clicked on cover, tanks turn around and move in the opposite direction I wanted them to for no apparent reason, and units just simply not responding to move orders at all.Speaking of moving and cover, apparently there is supposed to be some kind of automated snap-to-cover system in place. I've seen it work once or twice, but usually I end up with half the troops in a given unit hanging out in an open field as the rest of them hunker down in a tree line. The game lacks any way to tell units which direction to face or what kind of a formation to take; a major oversight given that the game seems to be designed to explicitly discourage unit micromanagement.Which is frustrating because the AI is terrible. Units will fire on anything that gets within eyesight, regardless if they can hit it or not. I remember one instance where I told half a dozen helos to sweep an area. They moved about one hundred feet, saw a single T-55 tank way off in the distance, came to a screeching halt, and unloaded every single rocket at it. They did little, if any, damage to it and I had to empty out most of a FOB to rearm them. Anti-tank infantry will fire off every missile they have at anything even remotely in range, and given the computers indecisiveness this usually means they expend every single rocket (with zero effect) before the opfor vehicles get into a more reasonable range. (I know the player can 'turn off' the weapons of the units, but then it's just back to micromanaging everything again.)That isn't to say the computer is smart - it's not, it's as dumb as a brick. The developers seem to have known this, so they compenstated (in the singleplayer campaign at least) by putting an absolute metric fudge ton of enemy units on the maps. Players are easily outnumbered four to one, by my estimate. The only counter to this is just throw massive groups of units at the computer - the enemy can't call in new units, you can - but this mostly ruins the entire 'strategy' element of the game. Your units are as dumb as the computers (see above), so any attempt to set up kill zones or perform interesting maneuvers is usually thwarted by some IFVs or tanks or something deciding to wander off on their own, or charge in, or just plain not move.To add to the problem the enemy tend to be super-human. One particularly notable example I can recall: I was moving into a small town and a single enemy infantry squad had set up in a house on an outer corner. Nothing special; just some rifles, grenades, and some RPGs spread among about twenty soldiers. Ten minutes later I had lost sixteen Leopard 2 tanks, and managed to whittle the unit (which had been under direct fire from the tanks the entire time) down to two guys. I sent in four Huey gunships to clean up and lost them all within five seconds to two guys with rifles who were hunkered down in a pile of gravel and splintered 2x4's. I shelled it a bit with artillery and ran away. I don't know if I ever actually cleaned them out.Oh yeah, and the maps are heavily scripted. It varies from map to map, of course, but usually there is a massive attack wave or reinforcements, or something that will spawn when the player invades a given objective or moves past a specific point. One of the early missions the player is supposed to secure a collapsed bridge with a command unit early on. Thing is, if you never capture that objective the reenforcement wave never comes in, which leaves the player with as much time as they like to build up a massive force or just bypassing the objective entirely. It feels like cheating, but in some cases it seems like the only way to complete the map.This game tries to sell itself as the ultimate strategy game but fails miserably. It seems like the developers couldn't decide if the player should micromanage their army or not, and as a result the units are stupid and the controls are frustratingly incomplete. The graphics are pretty good but given that this is the second game they made with this engine (R.U.S.E. being the first) I'm not surprised. I am extremely impressed by the level of unit detail they've built in, which makes the badly designed controls and pitiful AI seem all the more vexing.Not recommended. I suggest World in Conflict as an alternative, if you're a fan of 198X-era wargaming. It's not nearly as detailed in terms of units but the singleplayer plays a lot better. In my opinion anyway.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Having only played this for a short time, here's what I know so far:  The learning curve is STEEP.   The first missions will try to teach you how to play the game, but it's really going to require alot of guessing and clicking on your part to figure out what's actually going on.  The game basically has so much information in the form of detailed stats on each class, nation, and type of vehicle that you will have to meticulously study it to get any kind of proficiency when planning your battles. This game requires you to actually resupply and refuel your units with logistics and this is every bit as painstaking as it sounds.  Terrain matters,  unit optics matter, armor matters, weapon range matters, weapon types matter.  It's very complicated, but the satisfaction of success on the field is worth the mind boggling scope of what you have to keep track of, which is why you shouldn't play this alone.  You can team up with 3 other people on one side and work together and this makes it alot easier.

												This is a unique but very good modern strategy game with a lot going for it. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												A Solid RTS and probably my favorite strategy game serie (beside Civ)One of the best strategy games I've played so far. Balanced, Fun and Thrilling this is a one of its kind RTS set in a relativley unexplored histrical context when it comes to gaming. It requires great skill and the learning curve is steep but you will no be bored in this game. The Campaign (except for the first missions) is known for being hard and the AI is annoying. Beware, this game is exceptionally realistic. It's one of the few games I've played where morale, ammo and cover play such a great role. It really adds depth to the game making it's less about have more troops and more about strategy. The graphics are pretty impressive for a game that old and I was amazed to see the astonishing details devs put on the game's models. That's definitvely a game you want to buy if you have friends enjoying RTS's since the multiplayer community consists of a few hundred players. However, you WILL have the occasion to play a lot of multi and meet friendly people. Don't let the difficulty discourage you, This is a wonderful and quite cheap RTS though its successor are more complete.Solid 9/10

Posted: April 9, 2016
												Don't buy this game for the poorly made single-player. The rest is written only for the multiplayer part.This is easily the best release in the Wargame series. Featuring the most tactical and slow-paced gameplay of the three games. The diferent unit types here are very well-balanced, and together with the great map design every match will leave you at the tip of your chair. The only con is the steap learning curve, but it's well worth the time invested once you figure out how to compete in multiplayer.Sadly the multiplayer community has pretty much died out, meaning you're only going find full matches on peak hours.

Posted: July 14, 2012
												Fantastic strategy game, quite hard.In reality, it's a tactics game, the focus is completely on the combat. You can bring units into battle, but at a fairly slow rate, and only from controlled board edges. Posistioning and unit composistion are key.Has a nice campaign as well, set in the cold war, which allows a choice of which units are avavilable, as well as only have a limited number of each unit. Makes keeping them alive from one mission to the next important, which adds to make the whole thing more tense.Has a fairly decent variety of different missions as well.Should be a definite buy for anyone into combat strategy.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												This game is awesome! It has amazing graphics, tons of units, and a very realistic campiegn that alligns it self some what to historical events!Pros- tons of units- interesting realistic campeign- multiplayer- amazing graphics can be ran on a small computer- fun AI matches for practice- AH-64 Apachecons (no game has no cons)- like most RTS games this one has not developed an easy way to control units. The units are completely controlled by you, and will not function with out you every instruction. This is hard to do when you are trying to coordinate multiple groups at one time.- VERY HARD, this game is brutal with new players. It took me a while to finaly figure most of it out, but I'm not too good yet- a moral system, this system is very daring, and creative. It makes it so when a unit is under a lot of fire it can get scared, and run away with out listening to you. Unfortunatly this "Routing" is very annoying. Somtimes infantry can route for 5 minutes longer when the fighting stopped. Also units will route in the direction of the enemy. This feature can make the gameplay annoying, and I hope they fix these problems in future games...- I suggest watching Youtube if you are stuck on a mission, because they get very hard...This game over all is very fun, and I love the graphics, units everything! GREAT GAME!!!!

Posted: March 3
												Even if multiplayer is dead, the single player campaign is well worth it.If you like realistic RTS games, or would like to know how a confrontation between NATO and the Soviet Union might have looked like, definitely give this game a try.The game's scenario is set in the late 1980's. There's a large variety of units included. From the last T-34 tanks of WW2 up to modern high tech units like the M4A1 Abrams or AH-64 Apache and the Soviet counterparts to them.Also worth noting: There are no aircraft in this game. The only air units are helicopters. I liked this because it puts the focus even more on the ground war. If you want aircraft included and a slightly more modern setting go for Airland Battle.I had a lot of fun with this game.PS: If you're interested in this scenario look up the book 'Red Storm Rising' by Tom Clancy. It also deals with this specific topic and is a good read.

												I always wanted to try this game, but never got around to it. Life was just to hectic for me at the time so I unfortunately never got to experience the massive scale combat of Wargame. That was until my good friend Bishop so generously through the kindness of his faggidy♥♥♥♥♥heart so graciously provided a digital copy of this glorious and underrated video game. I had once imagined what would happen if the Cold War had changed temperature. With previous titles like World in Conflict (which has very similar gameplay mechanics) I thought I had experienced WW3 as it could of happened on U.S. Soil. But lets get realistic here guys, they arn't just gunna walts right through Europe without a ♥♥♥♥in fight! (Shout out to my boi's in Germany, Britain, and France I guess) When I played my first round of this ingeniusly developed war simulation I had truly felt like I was there. This was the the most accurate depiction of a Cold War Era conflict I have ever experienced. I had PTSD for a week.

Posted: April 22, 2014
												A very detailed, quite haedcore, but engrossing RTS. No base building here, it's all strategy. The only negative is the unit pathfinding. Try getting a column of your tanks across a bridge without tearing your hair out!The different types of units is vast and the more experience you get, the more you can unloock. You also get experience in the multiplayer and the units you unlock there are carried over into the sibgleplayer. I thought this was a nice touch which encourages you to play both single and multiplayer sides of the game. If you can overlook the unforgiveable pathfinding problems, this is up there with the best of the RTS genre.

Posted: January 21
												OK I have been playing Wargame: European Escalations for about 35 hours so have a a good understanding of the game, system and all that stuff. Having played Wargames, and simulations, and Ground combat operations from the days of rock, pebble, fist I have a better then normal understanding then most that walk the halls or the face of the blue ball. 1, I like the game. I dont like the light speed of it or the fact that you can not slow it down. The fast pace has nothing to do with the scale of the game. At squad, and personal level yes. Things get very fast after contact in the real world.2. I like the presentation of the units. They are a little messed up as to weapons, and capabilities. Case in point is the M-60 shot just as well as the M-60A3 for the most part. What made it different was firing on the move, and successive rounds after about 6-8. The M-60 had to stop as did all the pre-M-60A1 Rise tanks. I speak in generalities but for the most part this a fact. The M-60 could out shoot any tank from a stand still with the exception of the A2. Even then the A2 was dead on at 0 to xxx range. Missing a shot at anything under 1600 meters was almost impossible. Wear as hitting anything with any Russia/East Block tank at 1200+ was almost impossible with anything other then the T-55/54, and even then with the crews they had that was an issue. I could go on in greater detail but the bottom line was I was there.3. Position in Units. Well they do not always go to the tree line like they would in real life etc. More options should be given for the defender.4. Unlocking units is just crack baby stuff. People pay for the game, not part of the game, or a bit, they pay for the game, give them the dam game.5. Better crews/teams/units. FIRST OFF the BOAR had the most professional at the start of the 70s along with the Canadians. No draft per say. In fact the Canadians had the highest paid troops for many years, they just had last decades equipment, and gear. So for the US. UK , Canadians the cost of better crews should be one point from one to another. The Germans and French should be 2, the East Germans 3 and the USSR just keep as is.6. No editor. ? Come on. Give users an Editor.7. Smoke round would be nice, I even had a few for my tanks.8. Missiles. Basic rule is the East had crap, and the SS-11 was better then most of what they had. Also the ones the west had, did have had a vast range of effectiveness. The TOW was at the top, HOT was fast behind and so on. Redeye was the best of the hand held, and they had a system that gave them even more of a edge. TacFire was in use by most most units by 1976. Even the Brits had it by then.9. Oh the most glaring issue. The computer cheating thing is way, way, way overboard. NWIFH am I going to be fighting the full 3rd Shock Army with a fireteam. Yes I understand that makers playing the game over and over , and over x500000 think they need to do this, but no, and We the people have no idea as to what the computer iis going to do, and the Average person should be able to win 99.9% of the time in baby mode.I have real issue about not getting the full game, and the computer player overmatch issue (oovermatch is way to soft of a term for what these guys did). These kind of thing make me questioning of any design group that does it, and all products they have, or will have.In Short a nice game that needs a few updates in a few areas before it is something I would say needs to be part of your kit.

												This video features a non-biased quick look @ the game:


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Wargame: European Escalation' - (GeForce GT 640, Windows 10) 

			Views: 185		

			This game is available on Steam right here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/58610 A non-biased quick look @ 'Wargame: European Escalation' - 2 sides, 8 nations, and one battlefield: Europe!		

2 sides, 8 nations, and one battlefield: Europe!Wargame: European Escalation is an intense and spectacular Real Time Strategy game, where realism and strategy are brought to the front lines. With a phenomenal range of vehicles and units (over 350 different models), build your army and enter a huge military campaign across Europe of the 80's, as the Cold War is about to become World War 3.With the powerful IRISZOOM ™, Wargame offers breathtaking graphics and battles as spectacular as they are strategic. Prepare to bring hundreds of units of all kinds--tanks, helicopters, squad Infantry, etc.--under your command in intense battles on gigantic maps stretching up to 60 square miles!Online service EugenNet© provides a full multiplayer experience with creation of clans, organizing games, and world rankings where up to 8 players can compete simultaneously in massive battles involving hundreds of units!

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game a BIG disappointment for me. The graphics are terrific, and the game play could become addictive if there were not so many faults.  It appears to me that the designers either were not gamers them selves, or did not use (or pay attention to) beta players to improve this release.  After the first couple of levels the game uses foes (Usually russian) that are way beyond the level of units you are able to aquire. Also, the numbers of enemy units are several times what yours are. For instance: During a recent game, the axis sent 24 Mi24v Helo's against ONE small group of my attackers.  That does not include the other Helo's of the same type that I had already seen and shot down.  It is EASY to get lost in this...meaning, if you have to jump around some of the larger maps, it's easy to forget where a particular unit is located. (Easily fixed by allowing players to view a list of currently used units) Also, there is no access to play as the axis side that i could find.    With a little more thought about the player and his/her experience, this could easily be avoided or corrected. An excersize in frustration.....

number of helpful: 19 of 37 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Its hard to gauge wargame ee.  Overall its a fun game, but its mainly a multiplayer game and that multiplayer community has gone on to the newer games.The single player campaign is just kind of tedius and not fun and it really feels out of order as well.  You can only play against one ai opponent so not much entertainment as far as playing the ai etc.  Overall i hate to say it but i have to give a good game here a thumbs down recommendation.Which is a real shame.  This game has an impressive and realistic unit and weapon selection, the maps have a nice natural look to them, and the game makes you resupply your vehicles as weapons/fuel are depleted which gives you a feel for the nightmare of logistics for a modern army, and i think that is a very cool angle to go after.Im sure it was great when it was new, and you might try the new games, but i wouldnt recommend old games in the wargame series.  Theres just not all that much to do in them now that the community is playing the newer games.

												It's such a shame when a developer makes an amazing first game (RUSE) and then make another game which makes you want to tear your eyes out after playing it *tries not to look at Relic*Eugen Systems is one of those developers unfortuntely, and Wargame is definately a pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥that you will want to step around. Hardcore war-sim fans may like it, however, I refuse to believe that a tank driving for a single mile and depleting all of it's fuel is "realistic".

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Sadly, I really want to like this game, but I can't do so out of good heart. It looks fine, sounds fine, plays fine, controls fine, but I found it extremely hard and unfair. I play a lot of stragegy games and I like a good challange, but this game for me was very hard to play because you have little to no chance. Your units seem to be worse than the enemies' units, which would be fine, except they out number you about 10 to one. No matter how many units I call in, they always seem to have ten times as many units, and plus they have air support often when you don't, and captuing and holding an objective is hard enough, and gets even harder when you have to defend three points, while outnumbered, out gunned, and out maneuvered. I nveer got past level three or so, and I gave this game MANY tries, but I could never pull through, as misions can last for hours, with little to no progress made. As much as I want to like this game, I can't, and I have to recommend somehting like "Men of War: Assault Squad 2" or "Star Wars Empire at War"  or "World in Conflict" as opposed to this when suggesting a good RTS. Maybe I'm just REALLY bad at this, but I've played a LOT of RTS games, some of which can be very punishing (Men of War on veteran difficulty) and in those I still felt that I had a chance and could make progress and win, but in this I fight for hours and gain nothing but keep losing everything...

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												If you have a micromanagement fetish, you will love this game. There is no way, you will ever -in one game- be immediately able to select the unit you want to select. Also, the number of different units is sheer infinite. THis might sound like heaps of fun at first, however, this also means, that there is no way, that you'll ever be able to understand every unit's abilities and counter abilities in detail. Plus the toolbar, or whatever the heck you would call this thing on the site of the screen is way too useless, and lacks many abilities that are only reachable through hot keys. Thus, learning the bloody hot keys before playing is obligatory. Or you're gonna have a BAAAD time. I thought of it as the advanced version of RUSE, but this game stands to RUSE, like a rhino stands to a dolphin: They're both mammals, but looking closer, you might as well see, that their evolution spread paths ages ago.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Im not to impressed. Which was sad becuase when I 1st loaded it up I was very excited after playing through the 1st mission.I would love the hard LOS rules and need for recon if the AI seemed to play by the same rules. Early in the second mission I got swept by some tanks from my 4 o clock, who seemed to have no problems shooting through areas that completly blocked my tanks LOS. Later in the mission My units seems to be utterly incapable of lining up with cover. I had a tank plt where one tank on one end insisted in hanging out in the open while the far tank refused to leave the woods and none of them seemed interested in engaing the fricken T-34s from there max range who were in the open. which leads me to another gripe. Why cant I give orders as to when my units will open fire? If im playing an arcade RTS that doesnt track ammo I dont care if every one blows through ammo. However in a game that tracks ever single round it maddening to watch a line of tanks blow half there ammo at max range shooting at a 5% hit chance aginst units who are no where near being able to fire back. A few minutes later the same unit justs decides to watch a few ancinet T-34s as they waltz across an open field and actualy get a hit on my Cheiften before my guys decide to return fire.The resupply system is just horrible. Nothing like watching your recon elements run out of fuel over and over and over. And if your going to make resupply a critical aspect of the game you need to give me control over it. Its kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to tell me I have to hold a line aginst tanks and then watch my tanks get ammo starved becuase other units are buring resupply to refuel. Resupply also hoses combined arms. I wanted to use my IFV to suppres infantry so my tanks could kill tanks. Except my IFV were hell bent on blowing 20mm rounds on T-62s which blew through my resupply which starved my tanks. In the end I either had to "turnoff" my IFV or send them to the rear. Most of this crap wouldent be that annoying IF the computer followed the same rules. but watching a T-55 hold off 3 Cheiften IIs becuase of the "magic of resupply insta repair" pretty much tanks the illusion of realism

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Pretty much a multiplayer only game as the campaign is very hard (not to mention the first campaign you have to deal with getting nuked, no literally). In single player you're dealing with an Ai with perfect reaction times that is all seeing (as far as fog of war allows it to). This makes a strong opponent and for challenging matches... too challenging. Add to that you can't restart fully setup with your units emplaced, you have to do that every time as well, which is a good five or ten minutes (but does strongly puch you to change tactics, which may help). Makes the campagin just too much of a slog imo. Lastly, your vital weapons shots like AA missiles are entirely chance rolls which will make you frustrated the longer you play. This is a game of tactics, strategy, and random chance. A slow down button would have been appreciated as well as a pause screen to assess the scene, but no. Pretty brutal if you ask me!It just could have been so much fun had they toned down the difficulty a bit.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												While I appreciate the realism (persistent army between levels, level-up for survivors, fuel, ammo, logistics supply and command centers, lots of hide and seek), which is very nice and made me quite addicted for a while, I eventually quit playing for two basic reasons:1. At the campaign, you have very limited troops and resources, while the CPU can spawn units forever as long as they have the reinforcements points. So you either rush or die. I don't appreciate STRATEGY when you have to rush.2. Multiplayer, well ... you know how RTS multiplayer go, but in wargame it is worse because of the limited everything, so only the hardcore players will do anything, a casual player like me have no chance.3. There are zillions of bugs on the border areas. For instance, enemy units that retreat (rout) outside the map cannot be easilly target, and worse yet, they might just stay there. I lost a couple of cames because some stupid enemy unit retreated near a reinforcement point and any/all supply truck I called in was immediatly captured, but since they spawn outside the map, I could not send troops to capture them back. Some enemy units go to far outside the map you can't even scout/see to try and siege them, wtfSo: campaign: you are infinitelly capped against an infinite oponent, so you have to win while you have troops; multiplayer: hardcore made even more hardcore. No, thanks.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												WarGame: European Escalation. Here is a game that has what I wanted in a strategy game. Unit formations, experianced units that carry over and a touch of thinking on how to complele a mission. here is the problem. You have no advanage what-so-ever. yes you may have a unit of heavy tanks supported by anti air and either gunships or artillery. But when that really means something your units don't use the initiative thats been given them. such as 10-1 odds where you have ten units firing at four, the out com should be opfor loss. No the same four vehicle unit rides right up to you one and only command unit holding open your reenforcement window and takes it out with a guided missile at point black right infront of all your heavy tanks, anti- armor and and duel purpose anti air artillery. There goes the reenforcements needed to resupply and and other command you its you wanted to purchace. As for supplies thats the hardest thing to use sence every thing runds on supplies, there isn't enough of it to utilize to either complete all the objectives in the time alloted or to hold out with. AI is horrible when you have a hardden veteran who panics at the first initial contact and routs right but the command unit it was protecting thus exposing it. I would think a unit that's been through so much fighting would realize that I've survived this long in this heavy tank that my crew can it a flea at three miles away while it is moving wouldn't panic when the action starts. And lets not forget the coversystem for vehicles. You can hole them up in a forest or a town but the element of surprize seemes to be the trade off for range. Once in cover the range is reduced for some silly reason. and when the enemy spots you with recon a tank unit can roll right up and shell you at the same distance you could normally fire. Don't get me wrong. This game has a tutorial, the first campaign under the west germans allows you to learn how to use units. But when you get to gunships, they just don't seem to hack it when fighting softer targets. lets also not forget to mention units sitting OFF MAP and still controlling territory and firing away at your units WHO CANNOT FIRE BACK. Really? I lost a whole heavy tank unit to a tin can APC who just so happenes to be sitting at the edge of the map and I cannot kill them? Who test played this game? Ignored the indications where you set the objectives and FOB next to these out of reach tangos? If the Developers would take alook at these flaws and probably patch them maybe this game would have a chance? I'm not recomending this game to those who want a game where they can sit back and relax. this has all the qualities for Rage quitting. Which I've been doing for four days straight since buying it and the whole collection. For Fast play and russhing with no strategy. I recomend it because if you don't care about your losses or the chance to carry over experianced units. then build all your tanks and rush them. the russian AI does it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												It infuriates me to no end that the division (a theater level organizational group) doles out the stupid command points as if it were a parent in a candy store telling a child "Alright, here's $5. You can get whatever you want but only if it's less than this". A theater level deployment strategy doesn't work that way. The general draws a battlefield plan to detirmine how many of what is needed to ensure that the frontline can't be outflanked, and executes. Nobody was every stupid enough to deploy 20 tanks, 4 antitanks, and 4 antipersonnels across an area that was several thousand acres and expect them to clear it. Maybe you get enough points to get another 4 tanks in 10 minutes or so. Big deal.Be prepared to rage quit constantly. Mostly I know why what happened, happened. Usually the problem can be solved by deploying more forces, which you rarely have though.And just in case it wasn't clear, I have a love / hate relationship with this series.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												War Game RTS with strategic command points to unlock units as you progress through the SP campaign and deployment points within each scenario that allow you to create and deploy those units.  For MP you create a "deck" of 25 units which you then take into MP / skirmish games.Graphics are great: you can zoom from way out at "Sat View" all the way in to individual units.  The GUI is well designed.  The action is hectic and the AI is pretty good.  One negative for me (and plenty of others looking at the game's msg boards) is the lack of a "Pause" that allows the player to choose their units and issue orders in SP scenarios.  I tend towards TBS, so this was a major pain until I used "Cheat Engine" to allow me to slow the SP game down.  Obviously the lack of a pause isn't an issue in MP.If you like war strategy then definitely give this title a go.

Posted: July 22, 2015
												Started playing a year after i bought it, in general, it's a great game, and extremely challenging for starters. I like how certain units do better in certain surroundings, like tanks are great in open areas or hedges, helicopters dominate in open areas, infantry rule the cities/towns/buildings, ATGM and other anti-tank units do well when behind woods on an open field.  My only problem is that sometimes the game becomes too challenging to the point where no matter what you do(brings in 10000 tanks to hold alpha objective) you can't seem to win(all the tanks die from one helicopter that they cannot seem to hit ever). Still graphics are extremely good and no unit rules all of them(unless its a helicopter and you don't have AA guns). Oh and btw storming a city with tanks will never work for you but works most of the time for the enemy.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2013
												Anyone interested in RTS or the mordern warfare theatre, or both would love this game! Well balanced, with excellent gameplay mechanics and a variety of strategies and play styles to chose from, unlike many RTS which favour specific build orders or tactics. Wargame also provides a challenging single player campaign that is relatively difficult to complete. This game is also very in depth and is far from mundane. Cheap units, if used correctly and positioned well can turn the tide of battle against far stronger and more expensive units. Honestly a great game, 9/10 from me!

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												What a breath of fresh air. To someone who has inhaled a LD50 dose of carbon monoxide of course. Because the real-time tactics genre has been all but moribund the last ... decade or so? And 99% of what we got were substandard SC2 clones or even more laughably, Facebook/mobile/browser games that were sold to us as "strategy".But this isn't only a title of grand vision to create an *actual* wargaming video game, it's simply an extremely well-made and thorough RTT/RTS as well. Too often real-time tactics depends on overwhelming your opponent with your superior build order, to then overwhelm him with your superior unit composition, and last but not least to overwhelm him with your superior numbers (particularly egregious). All of this is a science in itself, a kind of meta-tactics, but not exactly what I am looking for nowadays when I want to play an actual war tactics/strategy game. Which is also why I think that while SC2 is an extremely good game, it's not an extremely good strategy game in the truest sense of the word.Wargame exchanges this meta-tactics for true operational scale gameplay (the step between small-scale tactical engagements like in most RTT, and grand strategy, as in a Paradox title) that I haven't yet seen in a video game. Perhaps the last such was Rise of Nations? My memory is hazy honestly. I was 16 when I last played that. In any case, Wargame satisfies that completely. Definitely worth a play for anyone into strategy or mil simulators.

												Fast, mean, unforgiving, put your tactical brains on overdrive and go to it. For me this is one game that delivers. Forget massing units and just pummelling a weaker foe. number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												This depends what you're looking for.  If you're looking for another Company of Heroes style arcade top-down action game with NATO/Warsaw Pact units, a larger scale and some plausible alternative-history scenarios, but with a fiddly UI, go for it.  Similarly, the game would be decent in MP, where the numerous issues with the SP campaign wouldn't apply.But if you're looking for "an intense and spectacular Real Time Strategy game, where realism and strategy are brought to the front lines.", as per the marketing spin on the Steam store page, try somewhere else.  This is barely more realistic than the latest Command and Conquer: Red Alert (indeed, the infantry in C&C behave more realistically than the stunned mullets in Wargame:EE).  Command and control, deployment, force mix, it's all over the shop.  A fun top-down action game it may make, but a quality, realistic RTS it most definitely isn't, and as I picked it up based on what the developers said it was, I'm rating it accordingly.Some really promising individual unit combat mechanics let down by horrendous level design in single player (ridiculously unrealistic force layouts, spawning at the start of levels with nothing but command units and a couple of choppers with the enemy within a couple of kilometres, and mission objectives that wouldn't have passed the common sense test with anyone with any military knowledge higher than a passing familiarity with Hogan's Heroes).  All being well Eugen improved with their sequels, but European Escalation was a hue step back from RUSE.Which is another point - the UI is appaling.  It was easy to play RUSE with a gamepad than it is to play Wargame:EE with a mouse and keyboard.  While RUSE's pad controls were well designed, an RTS should _always_ be better with a mouse/kb.And then there's unit behaviour.  Infantry suddenly come across an enemy strongpoint in town?  They'll sit in the middle of the street getting slaughtered, rather than take cover.  Clearly the NATO and Warsaw Pact troops selected as AI models for Wargame: EE hadn't actually done any military training yet ;).All is not lost, however - while Eugen still hadn't quite got it right with Wargame: AirLand Battle (Better UI but still no time control), Wargame: Red Dragon has an improved UI and allows you to slow to a very slow speed, enabling appropriate single-player command over a varied force on a large map, and lets you deploy a force of your choice before the battle kicks off, and is well worth a look for SP RTS fans with an eye for realism.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												"Deeply disappointing, I wish I could return it."I hate to have to say that about any game that I spent so much time looking into before buying, but this would be one of them. I have a history with RTS games, and while not my favorite genere, I was looking forward to a 1980's Cold War game that would allow me to move units around and let the computer do all the math for me. I also spent a number of hours watching the Youtube videos about this game and none of the issues that I found are in the vidoes or comments.Pro'sIts pretty if you zoom in and watch the units, of course to do that you lose contact with the rest of the map.Con'sThe manual holds only the basic functions and does not explain the Deck, Reinforcements, Stars or Points.The scenarios allow you to gain points which allow you to unlock types of units. From there you should be able to add them to a battle. However when you are in a battle, you get points, but you are limited to a certain number of units, which appear to be a secret cap number. When you unlock the units, yo only seem to get a certain number and they do not seem to be adjustable.Controls are managble but not easy and often you click a unit assign it and then when you think you are assigning another unit, you are actually redirecting the first unit.This game is also very hard. Even through the five starter scenarios, it was hair pulling hard. When I tried the AI play at easy, I would continually lose. More importantly, there does not seem to be an improvement each time I play it.I know that many of these complaints mark me as the fault, but this game does seem to be enjoyable to a very close niche of people. So make sure that you are one of those.Overall, if you think this will be any type of Cold War simulation type game, you will be disappointed. This is a poorer grade C&C with a Cold War skin. I strongly do not recommend this game, even for the $9.99 that I paid.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												This game has great concept but is poorly executed in some parts. Graphics are nice but where it fails is gameplay, it's just tedious and no fun at all. It was intended as a mixture beetween macro and micro managing your troops on the battlefield but the big problem is they can't effectively fight without your constant surveillance. I.e.  infantry won't take cover in nearby woods if engaged by tanks by itself, you have to tell them to. You have to tell your troops every small detail what to do and how to do it and in real time with so many troops it's simply not possible. Also the troops often execute your orders clumsily what only adds to the problem. The lack of any ai behaviour (beyond starting to fire and fleeing) in your troops is what ruins the game for me. Non-armed infantry transport and supply trucks are a major nuisance as well since you can't order them to leave the battlefield once they have fulfilled their function. You should be able to tell them to leave the battlefield via access routes. Also the armory is not easy to navigate and find troops you need, and having so many type of infantry cards with different transport is also clumsy execution imo. They should have put only infantry by type and then ask you to join desired transport card to them. This would make that part of armory much more clear and less messy.Command vehicle model for controling sector is not good either imo, you can spend plenty of time searching for a single hidden command vehicle while you have many troops stationed in the sector yourself, they should have stuck to the control point capping other game use.I do like some aspects of the game like having to supply your troops, limited number of troops ,access points, terrain effects etc however altogether they don't make a satisfactory game experience in a single player campaign... In multiplayer all players have the same hendicap and problems so I guess most of the problem are nullified however if you're looking for a good single player experience like I did I would advise you to steer clear from this one.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												This game is allright, saying allright meaning it's right but somewhat overall....okay. The trickiest thing for a new player to over come the menu looking like a christmas light show with lots of annoying people stood in the way whilst everything confusingly flashes above. I payed the game and realised it didn't auto save, so i played the game again and the menu being confusing as it is, didn't save. so third time lucky I finished the first two missions for a third time. I realised that hiding anything that moves in a forrested area means it can fire again and live another day as tanks, aircraft and men can fire several kilometers across fields and have an accuracy of a German pornstar on an American beach. Eventually the game started to get rather complex and I bought some shiny new vehicles are recieving the special stars for being a good boy and taking time to move some of my units from A to B. Several minutes of watching an anti aircraft vehicle take many accurate but pointless potshots at a meerely observing enemy chopper I realised the wooded areas are like training wheels on a bicycle. Moving away from them makes all your units run away, yes run away and the poor men feeling "worried" and "doubtful" it's good to know the men are worried as I send 15 tanks towards an enemy fuel truck whilst infantry fire from miles away with incredible accuracy. Or that they all run out of fuel and sit there defending the same field for the rest of the game whilst I call in extra troops because the supply trucks loose their supplies within seconds of leaving the deopt because they supply practically every squirrel with nuts and every mole with fresh contact lenses and you find your trucks moving back and forwards like a tetris game gone wrong when you place a long piece at the side of a 3 block and it dosen't quite fit. Over all the game is interesting and the voice overs are amusing, if anything the maps are too big for the units and it becomes a pain to hunt for enemies and you find yourself out of fuel in various parts of the map. There are newer games but people are talking about them like they are out of date milk and are looking for somone to come and find the lumps in it like enemy units on this game.Bravo! 6/10 because I like how the chinooks land when you don't use them for a while!
