number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												A game made by people who want real war but know nothing about it which is compounded by the utter lack of a proper UI units that are insanely unresponsive and controls that are completely lacking in way possible.  The game gives you zero tutorial so you are expected to not only get on the ground running with no proper training, you are expected to be "pro" at it the exact moment that you start playing the first "mission".  I akin the "training and tutorial campaign" to holding a new born child under water and expecting it to sprout lungs in order to compensate; that is not an exaggeration you will be hard pressed to enjoy this....experience.  The game touts realism but delivers none of it, it expects you to understand every single nuance about the game's mechanics right out of the gate and best yet, you have to "earn" the ability to call in units to even compete with the painfully obvious cheating AI and its superior units.  Mean while you are forced to defend significant portions of land with some of the most basic and painfully weak units in the entire game yet you are lead to believe that since this is the Cold War going hot that the East and West would be on relatively equal terms as far as preparedness and technology, but no by level two you learn very quickly that the developers know very little about the weapons of war during the time period.  This all carries over into multiplayer which by now is devoid of players, who have since moved on to greener pastures, so have fun playing against either max level players with all of their decks properly filled or....no one, or a friend who you tricked into buying this garbage in order to have someone to play with.    The general consensus even on this game's FORUMS is to miss this game unless you want the "story', which is the most forgettable thing about this entire game, and buy Airland Battles or Red Dragon.  They both are a vastly improved version of this…lovely package and there is no need to grind for command points in order to play the game.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Unforgiving to the point where it's more a battle to not burst into tears of fustration and annoyance when navigating the menus to try a diffrent mission, This game hold your hand for all of the first theater and then cranks the enemy up to 11 while leaving you and your equipment at the same level as it was when you left the first theater, And as someone who hates playing RTS's against players right off the bat, I wanted to break down and cry after 3 days of non-stop Poland is Not Yet Lost. And the other 2 (If you unlock the 3rd theater you're a god) Are just as hard if not worse. 90% of the time you're Outgunned, Outmanned, Outmatched, Out of Resources, Out of hope and ready to smash your keyboard over the level dev's skull, And thats just the start of the mission. Multi-player is alright but it's still fustrating beyond belife and you don't get any good stuff because it would just so happen you can't get anymore command stars to buy new units.It's well built but your hair will be grey and covered in bald spots by the end of it. 6/10 I literally cried twice while playing it.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												DON'T BUY THIS GAME. If you are looking for anything remotely like Civilization then keeping on going. This game is not like Civ at all. They made hti sgame way more complicated then it needs to be. I tried playing it and I realized "oh hey, there is a learning curve. Alright I'll try to understand the game". One hour later... "Nah, it's just a piece of s**t. No learning curve, just bad mechanics." For everyone that has played this game and doesn't like the mechanics, you will undertsand what I mean. Why would I want the management of my troops be that complicated?!?!?Also, an enemy helicopter took down: 1 AA Gun, 4 tanks, 3 Rifleman, and 2 Recon units. I had to call in 2 more AA guns and 3 anti-air infantry units to take down the enemy helicopter. Balanced much? And finally, the hidden units. Really f****** annoying when I'm just going along and then BAM! 3 enemy units appear out of now where and take down half my strike force in the area. And ya, I had recon units with me but enemy still hidden far enough away that it didn't matter.3/10, could be a lot better but the dev's must have skipped community testing.P.S. I forgot to mention this but the tutorial during the first mission sucks. Hard. Taught basically nothing considering how in-depth the game goes.

												I bought this game a while back when it was on sale, hoping it would be similar to R.U.S.E. It is to some degree but this game kinda kicks itself in the behind by forgetting the basics of an open world RTS. The game is terribly restrictive despite being an open map RTS, your troops are goverened by 4 factors - Physchological state, ammo, fuel, repair status. Fuel runs out within mere minutes, you cant traverse  the map without having to refuel once or twice. Most missions do not even give you the ability to refuel your army unless you are lucky enough to capture a suply depot. So far it makes sense doesnt it, but here is the restrictive part. As expected the A.I. is automatically in control of these supply depots and so they are heavily reinforced, making you use tactical moves to beat the A.I. However you run out of fuel in doing so, so you are forced to go in head on. Ta Da problem is here. The A.I. being a computer some how has 100% accuracy with their weapons so the only way is to outgun them in order to win...oh dear, you are always out gunned in the first place so here is 1st catch 22 situation. Secdonly you do not really have the choice of what units to deploy, there is a pre-determined list of which you can select (unlock) units or not. Its a tediout game, not worth the time and trouble. Buy R.U.S.E which is absolutely fantastic, and is extremely similar to this game in terms of game interface and strategy requirements. Finally one aspect which really didnt make sense to me...you are play as part of NATO...a group of countries whos military power and resources easily rivals that of the USSR and its allies...why on earth is the game giving you only 5 tanks to take on 40 tanks?? It would have been a far better game if there was some way of obtaining more units, maybe in the style of World In Conflict or even R.U.S.E. Instead cant help but feel this game suffers from COD syndrome...one man army against the world. AVOID THIS GAME LIKE THE PLAGUE!!I understand that i may have only played this game for 1.5 hours on record...however it has been much longer, and being an RTS fantatic...do understand the difference between good ones and bad ones as have experienced them.

Posted: June 26, 2012
												Wargame: EE is what RUSE should have been in the first place: a game that focuses on massive, accurate-to-scale battlefields, a diverse roster of units to choose from, and realistic tactics.  There's no basebuilding, no offsite artillery or airstrikes, no fancy RUSE cards - all you get are the units you spawn in and what you call in as reinforcements.  The units handle rather realistically too - many of the units have the strengths and weaknesses they have in real-life.Keep in mind though, it's not completely realistic.  Some abstractions were made for the sake of balance, a good example being the supply units.  Any type of supply unit and repair, refuel, and rearm anything on the field, until it runs out of supply points.  Overall, if you're tired of the typical base-building RTSes or games that are more about your APM/ build orders, then you'd definately find the game to be a fun change of pace.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												Wargame: European Escalation is an absolutely amazing game that breathes new life into the RTS genre. Pros:+ It has a very unique style of gameplay, and, in my opinion, the best campaign of all the Wargames (though the co-op aspects of the sequels are nice, the actual content and feel of those campaigns is lackluster). + I enjoy the feel of progression in the sense that you have to unlock command stars in order to buy the units used to build up your ideal deck, this also gives you the feeling that the deck represents your very own army.+ The game is visually stunning, the terrain looks beautiful and the chaos is immersive.Cons:- The A.I. in Skirmish mode tends to favour mass helicopter rushes at the beginning of the round, which leads to a fair deal of repetition and a significant amount of points spent on AA capabilities.- Being able to play the campaign missions with a friend would be super cool!- You rank up painfully slowly unless you play against other humans (which can make it slightly difficult to create solid decks for both NATO and PACT).Oh yeah, I think the multiplayer portion of this game is best enjoyed with a friend or three! Overall, I highly recommend this game. It's definitely one of my favourites!

												            I got the game and it was a good buy, I have to admit. There are a few thinks I dont like though. For starters, I like infantry. On war games I head staright for infantry units. In the modern times I guess they might be less important, but still. After playing the game for a total of around 5 or 6 hours I have concluded it was a good game, but the infantry in my opinion was too under powerd compared to the other units. AI and other players just spammed units, Usually, helicopters or tanks, but me, as liking infantry for the love of God, couldn't do the same with my infantry. I guess it makes some scince, but I personally wish I could have done more with my beloved grunts and air cavalry. As for the graphics, they were good for the size of the game, and the game era is a good choice, alot to play off of. 												            I got the game and it was a good buy, I have to admit. There are a few thinks I dont like though. For starters, I like infantry. Posted: December 2, 2012
												I recommend this with some hesitation.  Not for any fault of the game itself.  Rather, the game is too good at doing what it does, and that is simulate late 20th century combat at the operational level.The game will leave you feeling inept, as you barely scrape your way through one mission after another.  Even when you win by a significant margin, completing all objectives you will wonder if you could have done it better.  The loss of prized units is inevitable.  There are too many variables, and never quite enough resources.The game piles onto your shoulders increasing responsibility from the command of a few tanks to control of the evacuation of an entire army.  Is this good?  Is this fun?  Maybe not, but it might be something every arm-chair general should experience.

												Where do I begin. This game is amazing. Simple as that. Posted: March 15, 2014
												OK, this game is not for everyone.I've bought it yesterday and I've started the single player campaign. After playing the first mission I was pleased but not C&C Generals pleased. Then I've played the second.Damn this thing is hard. One wrong move and you've lost all your units. And no, compared to Ground Control or War in Conflict, it is rather hard to get your units back. Right now I'm still at level 2 in the middle of the mission.Then I've tried the multiplayer.Damn, that was awesome and intense! I've never played anything like it. After wasting half of my units in a stupid rush, the other player told me to stand down. He gave me some instructions and it seemed like no one was doing anything.He told me "wait and defend".Then I've got the idea of getting 8 artillery guns. He gave me some targets and the feeling of crushing entire battalions with every salvo is amazing! We were lead by 1000 points and soon, after I've leveled every enemy position with artillery we were ahead. In the last minutes of the game, the other team made a final desperate attack using choppers. In the last two minutes I've bought anti-air, sent it to the target (it is amazing how far anti-air can shoot in this game) and seen all his airforce down. The end?A tie but this was the most intense multiplayer match in my life and believe me, I've played a few.  For hardcore strategy gamers who also have a lot of patience, this game rocks.PS: I'm playing it on a ultrabook with integrated graphics. I'm getting 30 fps with DX 11 and medium to low settings. On DX 9 It's smoother than ever.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												A good game in my opinion.  The maps are large and very well done, the units are accurate and are very detailed, the AI works well enough in my opinion, limiting the need for constant baby sitting, though at times you will find yourself closely watching one or two groups of units because you cant rely on the AI to use them properly.The only problem I've ever had with the game is that at times it just becomes too big to warrant a 1v1 game, hell even in the campaign I find myself starring at a giant map that really serves to discourage me.   While not a problem, I find that the overall size of the game can be daunting to people, and is a reason why I don't play W:EE all that much.  Still it is possible to get past the size of the map, and a few other problems in the game (in my own opinion) and enjoy it.  Still, if you're an RTS fan, you'll enjoy this game, it offers some cool features, such as spending command stars to unlock new units for you to use, allowing for different combinations, especially in the campaign. Not to mention that the campaign isn't all that bad itself.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												oh well... what to say... what to say...I LOVED THIS GAME!!!!seriously, if you are an addicted or just an RTS fan, you'll love this game, I suggest you to buy this game first before buying the other 2 games of Wargame, (the airland battles and the red dragon), cuz the mechanics are complex, and you need to handle the land battles first before coordnating bombing missions while trapping the enemy troops inside a city for complete obliteration.The game is good in almost all the aspects... BUTthe AI just SUCKS, and that's why i like to play against the Commie AI, cuz it is the closest thing that i can get from reality.Check this out:i was playing against an Medium AI on the Siege mode, i was defending, and the AI Attacking.Fine.Set all my men into a city and started to gather positions ASAPAAs...ATs...those kind of things.OK! good so far uh?but then, when the match started i had to wait for about... 20 minutes to the AI to find where my troops where. and when they did find...i think the AI commander was like:"PUT ZEM CHOPPAHS ON ZE CITY!"and about 15-16 MI stormed the city.2 min later they where all dead...but, as i was fighting the commies, i think the game creators went back to the WWII tatics and created an AI with the "FOR THE MOTHERLAND" "tatics"so then.30 tanks and a hell of a human wave, stormed the city from some hill i had left unprotected (my mistake...)and just started running and driving straight into the city.I though it was dumb. but i paniked when i saw that more than a half of my men had died from that♥♥♥♥♥♥..but the commies paid the price and the AI retreated to its initial positions and the rest of the match was a boring game of "cat-and-rat" when i was hunting the commies down...WELL!thats my review!But for real, DOWNLOAD THIS GAME IF YOU ARE AN RTS FAN!really.I LOVED THIS GAME11/10

Posted: February 12, 2012
												World in Conflict + SupremeCommander + RUSE + RealismWith all the simplified games coming out nowadays, this game is pretty refreshing with a few complex features in its gameplay and the fact that it's not another FPS game. Wargame is a realistic RTS game with large scale battles and a huge list of units to choose from.Gameplay: Choose units that you want to deploy (from a list of units that is customizable) and choose there locations. Start by capturing sectors for a slow income for reinforcements (sometimes sectors can reinforce too). The team who destroys the most points of units wins.Few notes: Maps are huge, unit travel can take a while and requires smart positioning. Their isnt much microing and speed involved in this game compared to games like Starcraft but rather involves more strategy in position and right timed attacks.I'd say this RTS game is great and if you liked any of the games listed above, this game may be worth checking out.

Posted: November 9, 2012
												This is probably the best RTS game I've ever had the joy of playing.It has a murderously steep learning curve, you'll spend your first dozen games being wiped off the map by the communist hordes or being crushed by the gears of capitalism - but once you adapt and get the hang of it, you'll feel like the most accomplished tactician ever. You'll sit with a wily grin as your mortal enemy is lured into your traps, you'll applaud yourself for having had the cunning to have anticipated his next move.This is not a micromanager's game - you don't need to mash your keyboard like you're having a siezure to get things done. You don't need to open up the inventory of some piddling little pissant infantryman to give him more ammo. You're just a cold, calculating, scheming mastermind with a whole front to play war in.

Posted: July 17, 2012
												Set in the rarely explored period of 1975-1985, Wargame: European Escalation pits NATO (USA and Western Europe) against the Warsaw Pact (Soviet and Eastern European countries) in battles that explore “what could have been.” The specter of nuclear warfare loomed large over the real Cold War, but this catastrophic outcome was the ultimate last resort. Large, armored offensives through Europe would certainly have been the core of this hypothetical war; and this is what the game’s explosive campaign takes you through!

Posted: March 22, 2012

Master piece of a game for RTS fans.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Wargame European Escalation is a very unique RTS starter. You do not build bases but what you do have is many units at your disposal. This game involves more strategy then most especially later on in campaign. The realism reacts quiet well with your vehicles getting stucked in the mud because tires delaying their travel or your army being frightened because their tank is about to explode and them running away.The game gives you optional objectives in campaign which will give you more stars. Stars are used to unlock various units from tanks,foot troops,supply units and high ranged things. The game has kept me playing hours and I feel a sense of getting better as if I was playing dark souls and had gotten better. With that said I give this game a 10/10 for realism and the amount of strategy it takes.

Posted: February 25, 2015
												Pleasantly surprised with how enjoyable this sucker is. A nice mix of RTS, with light touch resource management. A lot of replayablility in this, which I wouldn't have expected at first...but I find I keep playing the same maps over and over again trying different strategies and different mixes of units. That is the blats of it, is that the units are relatively simple...but pretty varied and fun to mix and match up for different battle groups. Anywho thumbs up, check it out if you like RTS.

Posted: February 14, 2015
												This is a game for strategy lovers, not those CoH 2 small scale type strategies, but real actual war strategy. Be prepared though to spend some time (30-60 mins to understand the details and how they shape your platoon)  learning the game and understanding the unit tech info. This is a game about war. The beauty of it and the death. Oh yeas once you loose units through campaign they are gone, permadeath. Oh and you will need to think of supplies.The game is a grand scale RTS in that you are on a real battlefield where you can zoom out to tactical view of the whole map or on the shoulder of your infantry. The game has very accurate description of military equipment and units (with some that are a bit changed for game balance purposes).Pros:RealisticBig scalePermadeath that requires you to be responsible in leading your troopsAbility to customize your platoon, i.e. choose which units to unlockFree DLC'sConsUnderstanding the game takes timeNot that many people in multiplayer now (as there are now two sequls to the game, but I recommend this one as it is a good intro into the series)Sometimes you are forced to quick save/quick load as some missions are really difficult and loosing precious units hurtsOverall score 8/10 and a must have for any strategy loverMore reviews at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview/

Posted: May 5, 2014
												I bought this game when the price droped as I did not have the time to invest to play this against other players.The more modern equipment made me want this game as I like the cold war military stuff.But the game seems to have a pretty steep learning curve and I get the idea you must exacly do what the developer wants while playing the campaign or you are not going to make it.The realism is nice but I would have prefered some player preference options like showing the visibility range of a selected unit like we could in Ruse or weapons ranges would also have made the game a bit more enjoyable for me.For example I was playing on a level with a hill and the units  hidden in the trees would not engage a command unit sitting at the base of the hill for no clear reason , but i suspect there was an issue with visibility.Another improvement would have been some clarification of weapons, unless your are really into military equipment you have no idea what the weapon does except for what you can make from its name and picture.The campaign missions can easily take you an hour and more to complete.You also must try to loose as few units as possible because those units can not be "bought" in next campaigns when lost.Here too I would have liked to see a player preference option as it can suck the fun out of the game.But these cons are not enough to give up so I keep trying to complete the campaign levels.Thats why I would recommend this game but only to players who are looking for a more complex micromanagement heavy game in a cold war setting.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												Smart RTS with litterally hundreds of units to choose from; it caters to a wide range of strategies for every arm chair general.  The graphics are top notch; missiles fire off rails, turrets turn, guns recoil, terrain burns, etc.  Helicopter in troops to set up ambushes inside buildings or carefully maneuver a group of tanks across a narrow bridge to surprise the enemy in a flanking maneuver!  As you play, you gain xp both for yourself and your units.  Units are persistant through the single player campaigns, and there's a finite number of them, so the game emphasises on limited casualties.  As you gain in level, you pick up unlock points which you can use to unlock more advanced units of your choosing to customize your forces significantly.  The DLC's added a powerful Co-op mode to fight the AI, which is amongst the best I've faced in an RTS.  Great fun for up to 8 players!

												This game is very decent. It isn't what i would call the perfect strategy game but it does have nice graphics and good action and destuction between units. I would recommend getting this game if you have been waiting for a modern combat RTS that looks real. For anyone who remembers Command & Conquer generals, this has some of the same things. It doesn't have the economic part like the C&C so if you are buying this to replace and you are expecting everything that C&C has then you will be dissappointed. But for those that don't mind a little change, it is good. I would have to say that the controls are a whole lot easier to use than the old C&C series. Remember this isn't what you would call a campaign. This is a multiplayer focus RTS with a high intensity of combat.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Buy Company of Heroes instead.  Based on all the supiciously postive revies, I must be missing something, but I could not get into this game.  In fact, I hated it so much I'm going to write a review which I never ever do.  I read the reviews and though, "Great, a nice graphic strategy game.  I like and am good at strategy games, and it's $2!  What a steal!"  I want my money back.  As someone else pointed out, there's a reason they don't offer a demo for this game. The user starting interface looks like it came chronologically before Command and Conquer, and built on a budget.  It's so bad there's a tutorial in the game for how to use it.  As for strategy, I tried using my light vehicles for recon like they instructed, but learned the hard way that rushing is always better.  Honestly, there is more strategy in tic-tac-toe.  Touching on pacing, "slow and strategic"?  Are we playing different games?  One review sums it up when they wrote that the tanks would have to be doing 200mph to do the speeds they do in the game.  It's like controlling a million little racecars that all blend into the terrian and all have spec sheets that are longer than your arm.    And the tutorial throws things at you so fast and so poorly that your eyes will go cross trying to figure it all out.  "Press this button to group units"?  Why don't we send every enemy unit at you while you sort through our complicated menu screen to find that button.  I just gave up trying to find it, not that it mattered as rushing seems to be the better strategy anyway.  The learning curve on this game is more like a right angle!  As an example of how bad the tutorial is, I don't normally use tutorials as I can just figure out the game on my own, but the tutorial is preprogramed so I thought I'd give it it's go.  It took me almost 6 minutes into the first mission before I found my troops and were able to move them as the tutorial kept trying to point out ally units that were totally pointless to the whole mission, and my units blended in so well I couldn't see them.Additionally, the mini-map is by far the worst I've ever seen.  I felt like I needed a mini-map to understand what I was looking at on the mini-map!  It kept trying to show me what I can only imagine is the angle that my camera was rotated to in such a way to show what my field of vision would be if I was looking at the main map.  If that made sense to you, you might like this game, but I kept having to furiously scroll around on the mini-map to get it to go over the red blobs that were attacking me that I just gave up on the whole mini-map. Now, I love strategy games, and I have played MANY of them, both new and old.  But this game doesn't even rank in my top 50.  Want a good strategy game with realism and a myriad units?  I suggest Company of Heroes, and I would wager that CoH2 will also be good.  Can't be worse than this.

Posted: February 23, 2013
												A beautiful RTS game with a wonderful, user friendly interface and very simple controls.The game is easy to learn, but difficult to master, which is in my opinion-perfect.With literally hundreds of units to choose from, creating a deck (which determine what units you bring to the battlefield) is a game in itself.The graphics are excellent, and the ability to seamlessly zoom in and out of the battlefield at any given moment makes this that much easier, and funner to play.Also, unlike many other RTS games, the units aren't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.They unleash thier firepower without holding back.You see the true effectiveness of tank shells, rockets and flamethrowers as you would expect in real life.No bullcrap 10 shots from a tank to kill a single infantry unit.No. Infact, a single High Explosive Shell can easily knock out an entire platoon of Infantry.The game has a very nice random factor added to it.From accuracy, to firing archs, to critical hits of all kinds-It really does keep you on your toes.Although the gameplay is a bit slow-I might find it in myself to say that is a good thing.Considering the large scale of the battlefields availble to you, it makes it much easier to manage things, even micro manage if you have a quick hand.All in all this is a great game with many things for you to discover on your own.Hope this helps to make up your mind! :)-Jenna <3-

Posted: July 17, 2012
												Set in the rarely explored period of 1975-1985, Wargame: European Escalation pits NATO (USA and Western Europe) against the Warsaw Pact (Soviet and Eastern European countries) in battles that explore “what could have been.” The specter of nuclear warfare loomed large over the real Cold War, but this catastrophic outcome was the ultimate last resort. Large, armored offensives through Europe would certainly have been the core of this hypothetical war; and this is what the game’s explosive campaign takes you through!

Posted: August 12, 2013
												Definitely one of the sickest Real Time Strategy titles out there. Much MUCH larger than other RTSs, it feels like Arma from the Commander's seat. Simple yet complicated as hell. If you loved RUSE, Wargame is pretty much the sequal.  Uses the IrisZoom engine that RUSE used.  Set in the time period after Vietnam, the Cold War becomes a Hot War and you are put in command of NATO forces and PACT forces.  NATO includes the USA, Great Britain, West Germany and France.  PACT includes East Germany, Czech, Poland and of course the USSR.  Most notable is the scale of Wargame.  Be prepared to track hundreds of miles using Light and Heavy Armour, Recon units, Infantry, Artillery, Helicopters, and more.

												This is a game for strategy lovers, not those CoH 2 small scale type strategies, but real actual war strategy. Be prepared though to spend some time (30-60 mins to understand the details and how they shape your platoon)  learning the game and understanding the unit tech info. This is a game about war. The game has very accurate description of military equipment and units (with some that are a bit changed for game balance purposes).Pros:RealisticBig scalePermadeath that requires you to be responsible in leading your troopsAbility to customize your platoon, i.e. choose which units to unlockFree DLC'sConsUnderstanding the game takes timeNot that many people in multiplayer now (as there are now two sequls to the game, but I recommend this one as it is a good intro into the series)Sometimes you are forced to quick save/quick load as some missions are really difficult and loosing precious units hurtsOverall score 8/10 and a must have for any strategy loverMore reviews at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview/

Posted: August 2, 2012
												Coming from the same developers as R.U.S.E., Wargame: European Escalation may feel familiar in its large scale. Fully real-time, Wargame is a RTS game focusing on a fictional escalation of the Cold War into a full-scale war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. This game features zero base-building. Positioning (flanking, cover, ambushes) is everything: several well-placed infantry units in a forest can wreck enemy tanks, and a pair of hidden heavy tanks can tear up targets from long range. Deployment of units is handled with command points, gained through control of sectors. The starting allocation of units is determined by your active deck- one deck for the NATO player, and one deck for the PACT player. Decks are expanded through Command Stars, gained through campaign progress and multiplayer EXP. New units, such as the T-80 tank or the ubiquitous M1 Abrams, are purchased with Command Stars. The game is tough and has a steep learning curve, but few games are more satisfying to master.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Buy Company of Heroes instead.  Based on all the supiciously postive revies, I must be missing something, but I could not get into this game.  In fact, I hated it so much I'm going to write a review which I never ever do.  I read the reviews and though, "Great, a nice graphic strategy game.  I like and am good at strategy games, and it's $2!  What a steal!"  I want my money back.  As someone else pointed out, there's a reason they don't offer a demo for this game. The user starting interface looks like it came chronologically before Command and Conquer, and built on a budget.  It's so bad there's a tutorial in the game for how to use it.  As for strategy, I tried using my light vehicles for recon like they instructed, but learned the hard way that rushing is always better.  Honestly, there is more strategy in tic-tac-toe.  Touching on pacing, "slow and strategic"?  Are we playing different games?  One review sums it up when they wrote that the tanks would have to be doing 200mph to do the speeds they do in the game.  It's like controlling a million little racecars that all blend into the terrian and all have spec sheets that are longer than your arm.    And the tutorial throws things at you so fast and so poorly that your eyes will go cross trying to figure it all out.  "Press this button to group units"?  Why don't we send every enemy unit at you while you sort through our complicated menu screen to find that button.  I just gave up trying to find it, not that it mattered as rushing seems to be the better strategy anyway.  The learning curve on this game is more like a right angle!  As an example of how bad the tutorial is, I don't normally use tutorials as I can just figure out the game on my own, but the tutorial is preprogramed so I thought I'd give it it's go.  It took me almost 6 minutes into the first mission before I found my troops and were able to move them as the tutorial kept trying to point out ally units that were totally pointless to the whole mission, and my units blended in so well I couldn't see them.Additionally, the mini-map is by far the worst I've ever seen.  I felt like I needed a mini-map to understand what I was looking at on the mini-map!  It kept trying to show me what I can only imagine is the angle that my camera was rotated to in such a way to show what my field of vision would be if I was looking at the main map.  If that made sense to you, you might like this game, but I kept having to furiously scroll around on the mini-map to get it to go over the red blobs that were attacking me that I just gave up on the whole mini-map. Now, I love strategy games, and I have played MANY of them, both new and old.  But this game doesn't even rank in my top 50.  Want a good strategy game with realism and a myriad units?  I suggest Company of Heroes, and I would wager that CoH2 will also be good.  Can't be worse than this.

Posted: February 12, 2012
												World in Conflict + SupremeCommander + RUSE + RealismWith all the simplified games coming out nowadays, this game is pretty refreshing with a few complex features in its gameplay and the fact that it's not another FPS game. Wargame is a realistic RTS game with large scale battles and a huge list of units to choose from.Gameplay: Choose units that you want to deploy (from a list of units that is customizable) and choose there locations. Start by capturing sectors for a slow income for reinforcements (sometimes sectors can reinforce too). The team who destroys the most points of units wins.Few notes: Maps are huge, unit travel can take a while and requires smart positioning. Their isnt much microing and speed involved in this game compared to games like Starcraft but rather involves more strategy in position and right timed attacks.I'd say this RTS game is great and if you liked any of the games listed above, this game may be worth checking out.

Posted: August 2, 2012
												Coming from the same developers as R.U.S.E., Wargame: European Escalation may feel familiar in its large scale. Fully real-time, Wargame is a RTS game focusing on a fictional escalation of the Cold War into a full-scale war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact. This game features zero base-building. Positioning (flanking, cover, ambushes) is everything: several well-placed infantry units in a forest can wreck enemy tanks, and a pair of hidden heavy tanks can tear up targets from long range. Deployment of units is handled with command points, gained through control of sectors. The starting allocation of units is determined by your active deck- one deck for the NATO player, and one deck for the PACT player. Decks are expanded through Command Stars, gained through campaign progress and multiplayer EXP. New units, such as the T-80 tank or the ubiquitous M1 Abrams, are purchased with Command Stars. The game is tough and has a steep learning curve, but few games are more satisfying to master.

												            I got the game and it was a good buy, I have to admit. There are a few thinks I dont like though. For starters, I like infantry. Posted: March 15, 2014
												OK, this game is not for everyone.I've bought it yesterday and I've started the single player campaign. After playing the first mission I was pleased but not C&C Generals pleased. Then I've played the second.Damn this thing is hard. One wrong move and you've lost all your units. And no, compared to Ground Control or War in Conflict, it is rather hard to get your units back. Right now I'm still at level 2 in the middle of the mission.Then I've tried the multiplayer.Damn, that was awesome and intense! I've never played anything like it. After wasting half of my units in a stupid rush, the other player told me to stand down. He gave me some instructions and it seemed like no one was doing anything.He told me "wait and defend".Then I've got the idea of getting 8 artillery guns. He gave me some targets and the feeling of crushing entire battalions with every salvo is amazing! We were lead by 1000 points and soon, after I've leveled every enemy position with artillery we were ahead. In the last minutes of the game, the other team made a final desperate attack using choppers. In the last two minutes I've bought anti-air, sent it to the target (it is amazing how far anti-air can shoot in this game) and seen all his airforce down. The end?A tie but this was the most intense multiplayer match in my life and believe me, I've played a few.  For hardcore strategy gamers who also have a lot of patience, this game rocks.PS: I'm playing it on a ultrabook with integrated graphics. I'm getting 30 fps with DX 11 and medium to low settings. On DX 9 It's smoother than ever.

Posted: July 8, 2012
												Two years after releasing R.U.S.E,  Eugen Systems made a new strategy game, this time set in a what if alternate timeline set during the Cold War.The story follows that the Russians along with its Eastern European allies have begun an invasion of the rest of Europe following several high tension situations, including a real life event where a East German guard escaped to the West and killed two guards who were in his way.Like in R.U.S.E, you will be looking at things from above, but unlike that game you can actually zoom in and see all the details on the vehicles and infantry.During the missions, your units will gain combat experience from the battles they will be engaged in and if you lose them, they're gone and you can't use them for the next mission.The AI can be a little stupid at times, but it offers plenty of challenges that strategy gamers will enjoy.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Very fun, although I've only owned the game for a bit, I have a very good feel for the gameplay and a grasp on the whole of the single/multiplayer content. If you want a hard game, this game is for you. A lot of people talk about the cheating AI. It is likely that it does, but personally I enjoy the added difficulty. I have a feeling (from many of the negative reviews) that a lot of people don't know how to play this game properly. There is not too much to it, and the tutorial is there. It's called campaign missions 1 and 2. Play and you will learn. The landscape is beautiful, and the military units even more so.I do have one major gripe with this game. It requires you to get command stars through multiplayer battles in order to unlock all of the units. This seems like a pretty ridiculous requirement, since there are rarely any games going on anymore. You can also earn them by leveling up, but leveling up through playing single-player skirmish takes ages.I'd recommend this game to any RTS player looking for a challenge. You WILL be frustrated, just be prepared for that.

However in order to truly enjoy the game play you need to sink a lot of time into it for the aforementioned reason.Single playerGood campaign and interesting progression with some replay ability.An unholy amount of micro if you are not careful.Multiplayer [if there is anyone who has not moved on yet]Great community.Unfortunate progression requirement but not game breaking to have certain units.Wait for a sale

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Wargame: European Escalation and its later game Wargame: Red Dragon are shining examples of what RTS games should be. Well designed and masterfully researched, these games are a must own for an RTS fan. If you want to recreate what the cold war played out would be like.... Wargame. If you want to learn about the capabilities of different military vehicals from both sides of the cold war....Wargame. On a gameplay front, the game has a short, but steep learning curve, and only minimal tutorials. The difficulty curve on the other hand is rather....monolithic. The single player campaign is challenging and fun, rewarding those that really invest time in the game. Mechanically, the game is very functional. I wish some of the AI were a tad sharper or more clear, but it all works very well. While later games add new mechanics and refinements to the Wargame system, European Escalation is still the most functional of the games and the best way to begin a Wargame experience (Aircraft in Red Dragon operate by some sort of gypsy targeting, difficult to use well). Don't be discouraged by the difficulty of the campaign, or the initially confusing combat; once you understand how to play this game it is one of the goodies!

												oh well... what to say... what to say...I LOVED THIS GAME!!!!seriously, if you are an addicted or just an RTS fan, you'll love this game, I suggest you to buy this game first before buying the other 2 games of Wargame, (the airland battles and the red dragon), cuz the mechanics are complex, and you need to handle the land battles first before coordnating bombing missions while trapping the enemy troops inside a city for complete obliteration.The game is good in almost all the aspects... BUTthe AI just SUCKS, and that's why i like to play against the Commie AI, cuz it is the closest thing that i can get from reality.Check this out:i was playing against an Medium AI on the Siege mode, i was defending, and the AI Attacking.Fine.Set all my men into a city and started to gather positions ASAPAAs...ATs...those kind of things.OK! good so far uh?but then, when the match started i had to wait for about... 20 minutes to the AI to find where my troops where. and when they did find...i think the AI commander was like:"PUT ZEM CHOPPAHS ON ZE CITY!"and about 15-16 MI stormed the city.2 min later they where all dead...but, as i was fighting the commies, i think the game creators went back to the WWII tatics and created an AI with the "FOR THE MOTHERLAND" "tatics"so then.30 tanks and a hell of a human wave, stormed the city from some hill i had left unprotected (my mistake...)and just started running and driving straight into the city.I though it was dumb. but i paniked when i saw that more than a half of my men had died from that♥♥♥♥♥♥..but the commies paid the price and the AI retreated to its initial positions and the rest of the match was a boring game of "cat-and-rat" when i was hunting the commies down...WELL!thats my review!But for real, DOWNLOAD THIS GAME IF YOU ARE AN RTS FAN!really.I LOVED THIS GAME11/10

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Erm, what the ♥♥♥♥ do I do? What? What is tutorial? I have no idea what i'm doing.EDIT: Alright, I came back to this game after finally deciding to give the mission another shot.What I realized is that I, in fact, am a massive tard. I played it at first at like 1 in the morning so I didn't see the small rectangle that allows you to call in reinforcements. Regardless, I still find it a bit odd that not all of the tutorial messages are shown directly to the viewer (I mean the ones where you have to click a few times which reveals new chunks of info one by one before you're allowed to proceed). Any other tutorial messages are only shown on certain parts of the map or where a certain unit is, and they disappear fairly quickly making them easy to miss. There are some things I feel could be better explained, like how exaclty ranks work. There didnt really seem to be much of a difference (from what I saw) between ranks when I played. They're just kinda like "waow, u kild 4 HOLE tenks!! u ged a gol starr" :/ But it probably does have SOME use, I just haven't been able to determine it yet. All I really remember is the game saying that they're more effective in combat. Maybe something to do with reload speed or accuracy? Spotting? I don't know.Another thing is how -exactly- detection works. I had 3 british recon infantry units located in the   -exact same- forest when one unit was spotted by tanks and was promptly used to wipe the floor. Said tanks then moved into the -EXACT SAME FOREST- and my men couldn't spot them. Like what the ♥♥♥♥? Who TRAINED these guys?? Some blind/deaf/mute mother ♥♥♥♥er??anyways.The game is pretty easy to learn, hard to master. It's quite fun and realistic in the sense of weaponry distance limitations, visibility etc and the fact that I can damn well guarentee you that infantry will get ♥♥♥♥ing atomized by most full vehicle squads if they are not supported properly, as opposed to other strategy games where only anti-armor weaponry is effective against armor, and not say, a flesh and blood ♥♥♥♥ing soldier. In this game, if an explosian occurs 2 feets from a soldier, that guy is toast.Nay, BURNT toast. He's gone man. GONE.Which is a bit refreshing to see tbh. Though infantry do lack proper 3d models (On my settings they do. I have yet to get a good pc :[ ) Which was a tad disappointing, but ultimately meaningless as you should be spending most of your time zoomed out to keep track of your troops. Battle groups in singleplayer are also persistent throughout each mini-campaign (There's a bunch of little campaigns where you play as different factions in different operations which all touch into the over-arching conflict) so if you lose a unit in one battle, then you'll permanantly have 1 less unit of that type to call in in battles (within that operation) afterwards.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I feel lazy. I'm gonna end the review here. So yeah, if you like a good strategy game then this is a pretty solid choice, though I can't really give you my opinion on multiplayer, the singleplayer thus far is nice.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------have a good day. Don't fall into any spike pits.<3 Viktor

Posted: March 4
												For the wargame franchise, this seems to be a good place to start.Compared to other RTS-games and other games considering modern warfare, I think this game depicts it very well. It's giving me the feeling of Steel Panthers Modern Warfare, but real time instead of turns. I started out trying this one, and went on to pick up Red Dragon afterwards, but soon realized I wasn't proficient enough for RD quite yet. This game though offers sort of a step-by-step introduction through the missions in the single player campaign, and that can be very useful, since all game concepts aren't really explained fully. The lack of introduction to all game concepts is a drawback, but can be handled in this game with the mentioned missions. So if you consider this franchise, but are unsure about it and haven't tried anything like this before, I'd say this game is a good start. If it's on sale it's a very good pick, but the current price (€10) is worth it as well in my opinion.
